42.heading: Costa Rican Comic Books, Strips, Etc.--Articles About.
42.title: "Le Tardía Evolución del Arte de la Historieta en Costa Rica"
42.author: Óscar Sierra Quintero
42.appears_in: p. 43-51 in La Revista Latinoamericana de Estudios sobre la Historieta, v. 2, no. 5 (Mar. 2002).
notes: Presented at the 7th Encuentro Internacional de Historietistas, Havana, Feb. 2002.

Resumen: "El trabajo hace una breve incursión en la historia del surgimiento de la historieta como expresión artística de los creadores ticos, y donde se fija la pobre y balbuceante evolución de la historieta nacional en Costa Rica para permitirnos conocer las limitadas obras y espacios con que ha contado y las acciones de publicación en que el propio autor ha tenido un papel protagónico."

Abstract: "This article makes a brief incursion into the history of the growth of the comics as an artistic expression of the ticos creators. The poor and intermittently coherent evolution of a national comics in Costa Rica is observed, showing the limited works and spaces in which it appears and the acts of publication in which the present author has been an instigator."
Abstracts as published with the article, with some editing of the English.
Includes illustrations.

69.heading: Costanza, John.
69.title: Batman, Scarface : a Psychodrama
69.author: writer, Alan Grant ; artist, Charlie Adlard ; lettered by John Costanza ; colored by Grant Coleash ; separations by Jamison.
notes: "For years, Scarface has been one of the most brutal mobsters in the Gotham City underworld. But he is a different sort of wiseguy, unique among the criminal community. You see, Scarface is a ventriloquist's dummy, the mannequin mouthpiece of mild-mannered Arnold Wesker. It is believed that Scarface's savagery and disregard for human life is merely a sympton of Wesker's fractured psyche. But what if that outlet were removed from the ventriloquist's possession? What if the puppet were buried and left to rot? Would the evil truly disappear, or is this just the beginning of a darker, deadlier tale?" (back cover).

87.author: Dan Jurgens, writer ; Ron Frenz and Joe Rubinstein, art ; John Costanza, letters ; Glenn Whitmore, colors ; Digital Chameleon, seps
notes: Cover title: The Quest of Lois Lane.
Guest starring Wonder Woman, Lori Lemaris.

Summary: Lois goes to Bhutran in the Himalayas to investigate a heroin story and meets a priest who takes her up a mountain for a spiritual revelation, which helps her decide to go back and marry Clark. Mean while Wonder Woman is helping Superman investigate his lack of powers and his feelings towards Lois.

171.heading: Costanza, Peter, 1913-1984.
171.title: "The Apes Who Could Make Fire"
171.author: Otto Binder, script ; Pete Costanza, art? 9 p
notes: Introduction of The Ape Mastermind.

Summary: In central Africa (also called "darkest Africa" here) a big game hunter comes upon "natives" being driven from their villages by apes with firebrands. Captain Marvel checks it out, and indeed the apes are occupying human villages and using human weapons. Captain Marvel assumes a human trainer is behind this behavior. The apes can't talk. Monkeys and chimpanzees are also acting this way. Captain Marvel next finds a band of white men with firebrands chasing black people, and the men tell him how to find their boss, whom they've never seen. The "ape mastermind" catches and gags Billy Batson, and explains himself. He was born extra intelligent, and knows both human speech and ape language. He plans to conquer Africa, then the world, because "humans have ruled Earth too long!" The ape is about to throw Billy into a fire, when the human henchmen arrive, curious to see what their boss is like. One of them says, "We aren't low enough to turn traitor to the human race by helping apes! It was all a mistake!" The ape is put in a cage to be studied by scientists for the rest of his "natural life."
Data from Lou Mougin via Grand Comics Database Project.
